RT @VetAffairsDems Veterans should not have to prove that they were exposed to toxic substances during their service.

@RepSlotkin's Veterans Burn Pit Exposure Recognition Act removes this burden & concedes that veterans who served near burn pits were exposed to these substances. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyeDam0WgAs9SCO.jpg

As I told @SecVetAffairs in our HVAC hearing on March 25, we need landmark legislation on toxic exposure and I‚Äôm eager to work with my Republican and Democratic colleagues to get this bill on the president‚Äôs desk.

In instances where there‚Äôs not enough evidence to grant a veteran‚Äôs claim, this bill guarantees that the VA must conduct a medical exam to determine whether toxic exposure is connected to a particular health condition.
This bill would also remove the current burden on many veterans to prove that they were exposed to burn pits while serving so they can spend their time fighting their illness, not the VA.

This bill would formally concede that servicemembers in certain locations were exposed to toxic burn pits, and it will remove obstacles for veterans seeking care for the serious health issues caused by that dangerous exposure.

In order for the veterans exposed to dangerous toxins to get the care they need, the @DeptVetAffairs has to formally recognize the harm this exposure has caused - and that‚Äôs exactly what this bill does.
This story has been repeated by so many veterans across Michigan who are suffering from the effects of toxic exposure during their service ‚Äì think burn pits, PFAS, Agent Orange.

Some of the most painful stories I‚Äôve heard are about veterans - people like my husband or my step-daughter - who are suffering from strange conditions but can‚Äôt convince the VA that they need proper care.

Today I‚Äôm introducing the Veterans Burn Pits Exposure Recognition Act with @RepMeijer to help veterans cut through red tape and get care for conditions caused by toxic exposure. It‚Äôs close to my heart since I lived near a burn pit on each of my three CIA tours in Iraq

With these actions, @POTUS is fulfilling his promise to take meaningful exec. action to prevent gun violence. While these actions are crucial, we still need congressional action to reduce shootings & save lives. As Chair @SenatorDurbin said, we have a choice: give up or stand up.
And the President has directed DOJ to issue an annual report on firearms trafficking patterns and trends, which will help crack down on the flow of illicit weapons in and out of our communities.

The President directed five federal agencies to modify grant programs to focus more on investing in evidence-based community violence intervention programs. POTUS's American Jobs Plan also includes $5 billion over 8 years to support community violence intervention programs.

Currently 19 states and D.C. have laws which allow law enforcement and family members to petition a court to temporarily bar people in crisis from accessing firearms. DOJ will now publish model extreme risk protection order legislation for other states to consider adopting.

DOJ is also directed to issue a proposed rule to ensure when a device marketed as a stabilizing brace effectively converts a pistol to a short-barreled rifle, the device is subject to strict regulation. This type of device was reportedly used by the shooter in Boulder last month.
The President has directed the Department of Justice (DOJ) to issue a proposed rule to help stop the proliferation of homemade ghost guns, which are untraceable and often undetectable.

The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF) hasn‚Äôt had a confirmed Director since 2015. The President‚Äôs nominee, David Chipman, is a well-qualified and experienced law enforcement professional who will be a leader in efforts to reduce gun violence.

The National Firearms Act was enacted in 1934 to deter the circulation of firearms that were used to commit crimes by imposing a $200 tax on the transfer of these weapons.
